Title: Array.Empty for zero-allocation empties
Description: When you need to return an empty collection, use Array.Empty<T>() or Enumerable.Empty<T>(). This allocates a single static instance, reducing GC pressure compared to new T[0].

Title: Rethrow exceptions properly
Description: Using 'throw ex;' resets the stack trace. Use 'throw;' to preserve the original stack trace for debugging.

Title: SemaphoreSlim for async-safe locking
Description: The lock keyword doesn't work with await. Use SemaphoreSlim(1) with WaitAsync and Release for thread-safe async locking.

Title: Avoid multiple LINQ enumerations
Description: LINQ queries execute every time you iterate them. Materialize to a List or Array if you need to access the data multiple times (e.g., Count + Loop).

Title: C# REPL (csrepl)
Description: Use dotnet-repl or C# Interactive to test snippets quickly without creating a project.

Title: Use CollectionsMarshal.AsSpan on List
Description: Get a Span<T> from a List<T> without allocation using CollectionsMarshal.AsSpan. It is unsafe but highly performant.

Title: Structured logging templates
Description: Avoid string interpolation in logging. Use message templates (e.g., '{UserId}') to save memory and enable structured querying.

Title: Empty types with semicolon
Description: C# 12 allows declaring empty classes/interfaces with a semicolon, reducing boilerplate.

Title: Choose ToList vs ToArray deliberately
Description: Return List<T> if the consumer modifies the collection. Return Array if it is fixed. .NET 9 optimized ToArray significantly.

Title: Assembly markers for DI
Description: Use dedicated empty interfaces (IAssemblyMarker) instead of 'Program' class for scanning assemblies in DI.

Title: StringSyntax attribute
Description: Mark string parameters with [StringSyntax] (Regex, JSON) to get IDE highlighting and validation.

Title: Primary Constructors
Description: Define constructor parameters directly on the class declaration. Note they are captured in scope, not auto-generated fields.

Title: UUID v7 (Sortable GUIDs)
Description: Use Guid.CreateVersion7() for time-sortable GUIDs, which are better for database indexing than random v4 GUIDs.

Title: Smallest valid C# program
Description: An empty file is a valid C# program due to top-level statements generating the entry point automatically.

Title: Use built-in CancellationTokens
Description: Accept CancellationToken in API actions. ASP.NET automatically links it to the request lifetime.

Title: Collection expressions
Description: Use square brackets [...] to initialize lists, arrays, and spans in C# 12.

Title: dotnet-outdated
Description: Use the dotnet-outdated global tool to find which NuGet packages in your solution need updating.

Title: Waffle Generator
Description: Use WaffleGenerator instead of Lorem Ipsum for more realistic text data in tests.

Title: NaughtyStrings
Description: Use the NaughtyStrings library to test your application against dangerous or edge-case string inputs.

Title: InterpolatedParser
Description: A library that reverses string interpolation to extract values from a string based on a pattern.

Title: Alias any type
Description: Use the 'using' directive to alias tuples, pointers, or complex generic types for better readability.

Title: DateTimeOffset over DateTime
Description: Use DateTimeOffset to store absolute time with offset info, avoiding time zone ambiguity.

Title: Enforce architecture with NetArchTest
Description: Use NetArchTest to write unit tests that enforce dependency rules between namespaces.

Title: Assertion libraries alternatives
Description: Alternatives to FluentAssertions include Awesome Assertions and Shouldly.

Title: CallerArgumentExpression
Description: Captures the expression used for an argument as a string. Great for logging or validation errors (e.g., knowing the variable name passed to a check).

Title: CallerMemberName
Description: Captures the name of the calling method/property. Standard for INotifyPropertyChanged to avoid magic strings.

Title: Null Coalescing Assignment (??=)
Description: Assigns a value to a variable only if it is null. Simplifies lazy initialization patterns.

Title: Null Forgiving Operator (!)
Description: Suppress nullable warnings when you know a value isn't null but the compiler doesn't.

Title: Range Operator (..)
Description: Slice arrays using range syntax (e.g., 1..^1) instead of Skip/Take.

Title: Index from End (^)
Description: Access elements from the end of a list using the hat operator (e.g., ^1 is the last item).

Title: StackAlloc
Description: Allocate memory on the stack for small arrays to avoid GC pressure. Best used with Span<T>.

Title: SkipLocalsInit
Description: Attribute to skip zero-initialization of locals for a small perf gain in tight loops.

Title: AggressiveInlining
Description: Hint the JIT to inline a method to remove call overhead. Use only for small, hot methods.

Title: Conditional Attribute
Description: Mark methods with [Conditional("DEBUG")] so calls to them are removed in Release builds.

Title: Obsolete Attribute
Description: Mark code as deprecated. Use true to force a compiler error and stop usage immediately.

Title: Module Initializers
Description: Code that runs once when an assembly is loaded. Useful for registering dependencies or configuration.

Title: Static Anonymous Functions
Description: Mark lambdas static to prevent accidental closure capture and allocation.

Title: GetEnumerator Extension
Description: Add foreach support to any type by creating a GetEnumerator extension method for it.

Title: Using Declarations
Description: Use 'using var' to dispose objects at the end of scope without extra braces.

Title: File-scoped Namespaces
Description: Declare namespace at the top of the file (namespace X;) to reduce indentation.

Title: Global Usings
Description: Define usings in one file that apply to the whole project (e.g., global using System;).

Title: Implicit Usings
Description: Let the SDK automatically add common usings based on your project type.

Title: String.Create
Description: High-performance way to create strings using spans and a callback to avoid intermediate allocations.

Title: TryParse with Span
Description: Parse numbers or other types directly from a Span<char> (substring) without allocating a string first.

Title: ValueStringBuilder
Description: A stack-based StringBuilder (often internal or custom) to build strings without heap allocation.

Title: ArrayPool
Description: Rent arrays from a shared pool to avoid allocating large buffers repeatedly.

Title: RecyclableMemoryStream
Description: A Microsoft library that pools MemoryStream buffers to reduce Gen 2 GC collections.

Title: Source Generators (JSON)
Description: Use System.Text.Json source generators to generate serialization code at compile time for better perf and AOT support.

Title: Frozen Collections
Description: Use FrozenDictionary/FrozenSet in .NET 8 for read-heavy immutable collections. optimized for lookup speed.

Title: Switch Expressions
Description: Use functional switch expressions for cleaner code and exhaustive pattern matching.

Title: Property Pattern Matching
Description: Match directly on object properties inside patterns (e.g., obj is { Id: 1 }).

Title: Logical Patterns
Description: Use 'and', 'or', and 'not' keywords to combine pattern checks legibly.

Title: Positional Patterns
Description: Deconstruct objects directly in pattern matching if they support it.

Title: Var Pattern
Description: Use 'is var x' to assign a variable inside a boolean expression or complex condition.

Title: ValueTask
Description: Return ValueTask<T> to avoid allocations when async methods often complete synchronously.

Title: IAsyncEnumerable
Description: Stream data asynchronously using yield return instead of buffering huge lists in memory.

Title: EnumeratorCancellation
Description: Use [EnumeratorCancellation] to properly pass cancellation tokens to async iterators.

Title: Parallel.ForEachAsync
Description: Safely run async operations in parallel with built-in concurrency limits.

Title: PeriodicTimer
Description: Use PeriodicTimer for async loops instead of Task.Delay to avoid timer drift.

Title: Records
Description: Use 'record' for immutable reference types with value-based equality.

Title: Record Structs
Description: Use 'record struct' for lightweight, stack-allocated immutable data.

Title: With Expression
Description: Use 'with' to create a non-destructive copy of a record with modified properties.

Title: Init Only Setters
Description: Use 'init' setters to allow object initialization while keeping properties immutable post-creation.

Title: Required Members
Description: Use 'required' keyword to enforce property initialization at compile time.

Title: Extension Methods on Interfaces
Description: Add default implementation behavior to interfaces without breaking existing classes.

Title: Local Functions vs Lambdas
Description: Prefer local functions for better performance and easier debugging compared to Func<> delegates.

Title: Static Local Functions
Description: Use static on local functions to prevent accidental variable capture and allocation.

Title: Using Alias Directives
Description: Alias complex tuples or generics (using Grid = List<List<int>>) for readability.

Title: User Secrets
Description: Never store secrets in code. Use the dotnet user-secrets tool for local dev.

Title: EditorConfig (Formatting)
Description: Enforce code style rules across your team automatically.

Title: Polyfills
Description: Use polyfill packages to enable newer C# features on older .NET runtimes.

Title: Benchmarks
Description: Always measure, don't guess. Use BenchmarkDotNet to verify performance claims.

Title: Disassembler
Description: Use SharpLab.io or plugins to see the IL/Assembly code your C# generates.

Title: NuGet Package Explorer
Description: Inspect the contents and metadata of NuGet packages before installing them.

Title: DI Scopes
Description: Understand Transient vs Scoped vs Singleton to avoid memory leaks (Captive Dependencies).

Title: Keyed Services
Description: (NET 8) Register multiple implementations of an interface and retrieve them by key.

Title: Lazy<T>
Description: Use Lazy<T> for expensive objects that might not always be needed in a request.

Title: Scrutor
Description: Library to scan assemblies and auto-register services in DI by convention (e.g., all classes implementing IRepository).

Title: Options Pattern
Description: Bind configuration to strong types using IOptions<T> instead of reading raw strings.

Title: Options Validation
Description: Use DataAnnotations on Options classes to validate config at startup.

Title: Feature Flags
Description: Use Microsoft.FeatureManagement to toggle features on/off without redeploying.

Title: Memory<T>
Description: Use Memory<T> to store span-like data on the heap or pass it to async methods.

Title: Ref Structs
Description: Force types to be stack-only (like Span) to ensure zero GC allocation.

Title: In Parameter Modifier
Description: Pass large structs by reference (read-only) to avoid copying overhead.

Title: Out Parameter Modifier
Description: Use 'out' to return multiple values from a method (though tuples are often cleaner now).

Title: Ref Parameter Modifier
Description: Pass variables by reference to allow the method to modify the original variable.

Title: Scoped Ref
Description: Constrain the lifetime of a ref to the current method scope for safety.

Title: Unsafe Code
Description: Use 'unsafe' blocks for pointer arithmetic when raw performance is critical.

Title: EditorConfig
Description: Enforce code style and formatting rules across the team using an .editorconfig file.

Title: TreatWarningsAsErrors
Description: Force warnings to break the build in CI to maintain high code quality.

Title: Analyzers
Description: Install Roslyn Analyzers to automatically detect bugs and enforce best practices in the editor.

Title: BannedApiAnalyzers
Description: Use this analyzer to prevent usage of dangerous APIs (e.g., DateTime.Now) across the team.

Title: Module Initializers
Description: Run code automatically when an assembly loads using [ModuleInitializer].

Title: Function Pointers
Description: Use C# 9 function pointers (delegate*) for high-performance interop scenarios.

Title: Unsafe Code (Pointers)
Description: (Reiteration) Access memory directly for interop or optimization.

Title: Native Integers (nint)
Description: Use 'nint' for integers that match the native pointer size (32 or 64 bit).

Title: Checked/Unchecked
Description: Use checked context to throw overflow exceptions, unchecked for performance.

Title: Volatile Keyword
Description: Ensure a field is read from memory every time (no register caching) for threads.

Title: Interlocked
Description: Atomic operations (Increment, Exchange) for variables shared between threads.

Title: Discards for unused deconstruction
Description: Use underscore (_) to discard unused values when deconstructing tuples.

Title: Raw string literals
Description: Use triple quotes for multi-line strings that ignore escape characters.

Title: SetsRequiredMembers attribute
Description: Use [SetsRequiredMembers] on custom constructors that handle required properties manually.

Title: Init keyword polyfill
Description: Enable 'init' on older runtimes by defining the IsExternalInit class manually.

Title: CollectionBuilder attribute
Description: Enable collection expressions for custom types using the [CollectionBuilder] attribute.

Title: Avoid boolean parameters
Description: Replace parameters like SetActive(true) with explicit methods Activate() / Deactivate().

Title: Never block threads with Thread.Sleep
Description: Always use await Task.Delay() instead of Thread.Sleep() to avoid blocking threads.

Title: String concatenation with null
Description: String + null results in the original string (null is treated as empty). Be careful of masked bugs.

Title: Static abstract members
Description: Interfaces can now have static abstract members, enabling Generic Math patterns.

Title: The field keyword
Description: (C# 13) Access auto-property backing fields using 'field' keyword.

Title: Sealed classes
Description: Seal classes by default to improve performance and prevent unintended inheritance.

Title: Method groups
Description: Pass methods directly (Method) instead of delegates (x => Method(x)) for cleaner code.

Title: Pre-size List capacity
Description: Pass capacity to List constructor to avoid resizing overhead.

Title: Structured logging over interpolation
Description: (Same as Tip 7) Use templates for logging to save memory.

Title: Avoid async work in constructors
Description: Don't block constructors with .Result. Use async factory methods.

Title: Use ConcurrentDictionary
Description: Prefer ConcurrentDictionary over manually locking a Dictionary.

Title: Pre-size Dictionary capacity
Description: Pass capacity to Dictionary constructor to avoid resizing/rehashing.

Title: Use TrimExcess
Description: Use TrimExcess() to free unused memory in large lists that have shrunk.

Title: IsNullOrWhiteSpace vs IsNullOrEmpty
Description: IsNullOrWhiteSpace covers null, empty, and ' ' strings. Usually safer for input validation.

Title: Default vs Class vs Struct
Description: default(Struct) is a zeroed instance; default(Class) is null.

Title: Immutable properties with Init
Description: Use 'init' setters to enforce immutability after construction.

Title: Swap values with tuples
Description: Swap variables using (a, b) = (b, a).

Title: Dispose CancellationTokenSource
Description: Always dispose CTS to free the underlying timer resources.

Title: Pattern matching variable declaration
Description: Check type and declare variable in one line: if (obj is User u).

Title: Stopwatch.GetTimestamp
Description: Use Stopwatch.GetTimestamp() for high-precision benchmarking instead of DateTime.

Title: CountBy
Description: (NET 9) efficiently count key occurrences in a collection without grouping.

Title: AggregateBy
Description: (NET 9) Perform aggregations on groups without grouping the whole collection.

Title: Index (NET 9)
Description: New indexing features in .NET 9 allow for cleaner access patterns.

Title: Closures
Description: Be aware that capturing variables in lambdas extends their lifetime.

Title: Interceptors
Description: (C# 12) Advanced feature allowing source generators to hijack method calls at compile time.

Title: Inline Arrays
Description: Fixed-size struct arrays that avoid heap allocation. Great for small buffers.

Title: AsNoTracking
Description: Use AsNoTracking for read-only EF Core queries to skip change tracking overhead.

Title: ExecuteUpdate
Description: Update multiple rows in EF Core 7+ without loading entities into memory.

Title: ExecuteDelete
Description: Delete multiple rows in EF Core 7+ with a single SQL command.

Title: Compile Queries
Description: Pre-compile EF Core queries to skip the query translation phase on subsequent executions.

Title: DbContext Pooling
Description: Reuse DbContext instances to save on allocation costs in high-throughput apps.

Title: Compiled Models
Description: Optimize EF Core startup time by pre-compiling the model metadata.

Title: Migration Bundles
Description: Package EF migrations into a standalone executable for safer deployments.

Title: Split Queries
Description: Use AsSplitQuery to avoid cartesian explosion when loading related collections.

Title: Filtered Include
Description: Apply Where clauses directly inside .Include() to load only specific related data.

Title: Temporal Tables
Description: Use SQL Server Temporal Tables with EF Core to automatically track data history.

Title: JSON Columns
Description: EF Core 7+ supports mapping properties to JSON columns in SQL Server/Postgres.

Title: Bulk Updates
Description: Use libraries or new EF features to handle bulk inserts/updates efficiently.

Title: HybridCache
Description: (NET 9) New caching abstraction that combines in-memory and distributed caching (like Redis).

Title: OutputCaching
Description: Cache entire HTTP responses in ASP.NET Core with highly configurable policies.

Title: ResponseCompression
Description: Compress API responses (Gzip/Brotli) to reduce bandwidth usage.

Title: RateLimiting
Description: Protect APIs with built-in rate limiting policies (FixedWindow, TokenBucket).

Title: YARP
Description: Build high-performance reverse proxies in C# using YARP.

Title: Header Propagation
Description: Automatically forward headers (like Correlation IDs) to downstream services.

Title: Health Checks
Description: Expose health endpoints for load balancers and monitoring tools.

Title: FastEndpoints
Description: A library alternative to Controllers/Minimal APIs that organizes code by feature (REPR pattern).

Title: Carter
Description: A library extending Minimal APIs to help organize endpoints into modules.

Title: Channels
Description: Use System.Threading.Channels for high-perf producer/consumer queues.

Title: Parallel.ForEachAsync
Description: Efficiently process collections in parallel with async support and concurrency limits.

Title: Polly
Description: Resilience library for retries, circuit breakers, and timeouts. Essential for microservices.

Title: Deterministic Builds
Description: Set <Deterministic>true</Deterministic> for reproducible build outputs.

Title: Directory.Build.props
Description: Use this file to enforce settings (like Nullable, ImplicitUsings) across all projects in a solution.

Title: Minimal APIs
Description: Use Minimal APIs for lower overhead and simpler syntax than Controllers.

Title: Endpoint Filters
Description: Use filters in Minimal APIs to run validation or logging logic before endpoints.

Title: TypedResults
Description: Return TypedResults in Minimal APIs for better unit testing support.

Title: Short Circuit
Description: Bypass middleware for static assets using .ShortCircuit() in Minimal APIs.

Title: Route Groups
Description: Group Minimal API endpoints to share prefixes, tags, and filters.

Title: AsParameters
Description: Bind complex argument lists in Minimal APIs to a single object/record.

Title: Form Binding
Description: Bind multipart/form-data requests directly to objects in Minimal APIs.

Title: HTTP Repl
Description: Explore APIs via CLI using 'dotnet httprepl' (cd, ls, get).

Title: Insomnia/Postman
Description: Use dedicated API clients for testing complex requests and auth flows.

Title: API Versioning
Description: Always implement versioning (URL/Header) to avoid breaking changes.

Title: Global Exception Handling
Description: Use IExceptionHandler for a standardized error handling pipeline.

Title: Problem Details
Description: Use the RFC 7807 ProblemDetails standard for consistent API error responses (Type, Title, Status).

Title: Serilog
Description: Replace the default logger with Serilog for advanced structured logging, enrichment, and output sinks.

Title: OpenTelemetry
Description: Adopt OTEL for standardized observability across your distributed systems.

Title: Metrics API
Description: Use System.Diagnostics.Metrics (Meters) instead of Stopwatch for observability.

Title: Distributed Tracing
Description: Track requests across microservices using ActivitySource and W3C TraceContext.

Title: Logging Best Practices
Description: Use structured logging and avoid logging sensitive data (PII).

Title: Security Headers
Description: Add security headers (HSTS, CSP) to responses to protect users.

Title: No User Secrets in Prod
Description: Never use User Secrets in production; use Key Vaults instead.

Title: OWASP Top 10
Description: Study common vulnerabilities like Injection and Broken Auth to secure apps.

Title: Data Protection API
Description: Use DPAPI to encrypt sensitive data at rest using the machine key.

Title: Validation
Description: Use FluentValidation to separate validation rules from data models.

Title: MediatR Pipeline Behaviors
Description: Implement cross-cutting concerns like validation/logging once in a pipeline behavior.

Title: CQRS
Description: Command Query Responsibility Segregation. Split read and write models.

Title: Event Sourcing
Description: Store state as a sequence of events rather than current values.

Title: Domain Driven Design
Description: Align software design with business domain complexity (Aggregates, Value Objects).

Title: Modular Monolith
Description: Build monoliths with enforced module boundaries to ease future microservice splits.

Title: Vertical Slice Architecture
Description: Organize code by feature instead of layers to reduce complexity and coupling.

Title: Clean Architecture
Description: Separate Domain, Application, and Infrastructure layers strictly.

Title: Hexagonal Architecture
Description: Ports and Adapters. Isolate core logic from external concerns like DBs or UIs.

Title: Event Driven Architecture
Description: Decouple services by communicating via asynchronous events (Service Bus).

Title: Saga Pattern
Description: Manage distributed transactions across services using Sagas (Orchestration/Choreography).

Title: REPR Pattern
Description: Request-Endpoint-Response. Treat API endpoints as standalone handlers.

Title: Strangler Fig Pattern
Description: Migrate legacy systems by gradually replacing functionality with new services.

Title: Sidecar Pattern
Description: Offload common tasks (logging, proxying) to a separate process/container.

Title: BFF Pattern
Description: Backend for Frontend. Create specific API gateways for different clients (Mobile vs Web).

Title: Fuzz Testing
Description: Test apps with random, invalid data to find edge cases and crashes.

Title: AOT Compilation
Description: Use Native AOT for faster startup and lower memory footprint in serverless/CLI apps.

Title: SIMD
Description: Use Vector<T> to perform hardware-accelerated parallel math operations.

Title: Hardware Intrinsics
Description: Access CPU-specific instructions (AVX2, BMI) directly in C# for max speed.

Title: Testcontainers
Description: Use Testcontainers for integration tests to spin up real Docker instances of DBs/Services.

Title: .NET Aspire
Description: Use Aspire for orchestrating local development of distributed cloud-native apps.

Title: Keep Learning
Description: Stay curious and updated with new .NET versions to keep your skills sharp.
